timeline.message:
Cache current address book

Signed-off-by: Ian Jungmann <ian.jungmann@hedera.com>

Refactor to not pull in static string

Add test for repository layer

Signed-off-by: Ian Jungmann <ian.jungmann@hedera.com>

timeline.bodyText:
Will this break if someone renames the parameter?
If so use p1

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                        "#encodedFileId", unless = "#result == null")
          
          
            
                        "{#p1}", unless = "#result == null")
timeline.author: Nana-EC

replies.bodyText: This was refactored to work on the service layer which changed with the key params, but good point.
replies.author: ijungmann

timeline.author: Nana-EC

replies.bodyText: Unless there's a reason otherwise
replies.author: Nana-EC

replies.bodyText: This was removed since the annotation can just be used, but you are correct that this should have been done.
replies.author: ijungmann

timeline.bodyText: Add a test for the cache eviction scenario if possible
timeline.author: Nana-EC

replies.bodyText: Perhaps this test needs to be renamed to cacheAndEvictAddressBook, it does do an update/eviction and confirms that it was removed from the cache.
replies.author: ijungmann

timeline.bodyText:
What happens if an error occurs before addressBookRepository.save() is called?
Would the last valid address book be evicted from the cache?
timeline.author: Nana-EC

replies.bodyText:
Also what about when addressBookRepository.save() is called in parse() then an error occurs after?
Should we be evicting the new valid address book?
replies.author: Nana-EC

replies.bodyText: After refactoring, the evict cache is called at the resolution of the method via an annotation.  That being said, it will not execute if an exception is thrown, I'm trying to evaluate if that is the best way to go or if it needs to switch back to something that fires regardless.
replies.author: ijungmann

replies.bodyText: At 5mins it's probably not a big deal, though if your research shows otherwise you can add it in a follow up PR.
replies.author: Nana-EC

timeline.bodyText: Should be able to just put @CacheEvict(...) on AddressBookService.update() instead of this manual invocation.
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

timeline.bodyText: I think we're caching at the wrong layer here. We should not cache the repository but the service layer as caching here can cause problems with AddressBookServiceImpl.updatePreviousAddressBook().
timeline.author: steven-sheehy
steven-sheehy
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -90,7 +102,6 @@ public void update(FileData fileData) {
     public AddressBook getCurrent() {

timeline.bodyText:
I believe it was a mistake for us to have this catch here.
The result is an error parsing a valid address book would be caught and we wouldn't retry the whole file.
Can you remove this catch all together.
There shouldn't be any fallout in this minor refactor but let me know if you hit a snag as you address comments that makes it a bigger ask
timeline.author: Nana-EC

replies.bodyText: Removed, all seems well with the tests
replies.author: ijungmann

timeline.message:
Address PR comments to move caching fully to service layer

Signed-off-by: Ian Jungmann <ian.jungmann@hedera.com>

timeline.bodyText: I'm hesitant to use a never expiring cache for such an important object. If we have a bug it will never self correct. We use the never expire cache only for entity IDs as they're insert only and not updateable like an address book. Even 30m might be too long and we can get away with much shorter without impacting performance. I think the cacheManager5m might be more appropriate.
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText: That logic makes sense, I've knocked it down to the 5m manager.
replies.author: ijungmann

timeline.bodyText:
Since we're effectively evicting all entries in the cache (one 102 file), we can just do the following and avoid the reflection penalty of using Spel expressions:
@CacheEvict(allEntries = true)
timeline.author: steven-sheehy
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -63,6 +68,8 @@
      * @param fileData file data entry containing address book bytes
      */
     @Override
+    @CacheEvict(cacheNames = ADDRESS_BOOK_CACHE_NAME, cacheManager = NEVER_EXPIRE_LARGE, key =
+            "#root.target.ADDRESS_BOOK_102_ENTITY_ID.getId()")

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: ijungmann

replies.bodyText: I am slightly concerned that the cache evict annotation, coupled with the removal of the top level catch as suggested by Nana, causes any exception that bubbles up to not evict the cache, as this fires at the resolution of the method.
replies.author: ijungmann

timeline.bodyText: Use @CacheConfig(cacheNames = "current_102_address_book", cacheManager = "cacheManager5m") at the class level to stay DRY.
timeline.author: steven-sheehy
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -63,6 +68,8 @@
      * @param fileData file data entry containing address book bytes
      */
     @Override
+    @CacheEvict(cacheNames = ADDRESS_BOOK_CACHE_NAME, cacheManager = NEVER_EXPIRE_LARGE, key =

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: ijungmann

timeline.bodyText: Since there's current and historical and 101 and 102 address books, we should name this to indicate it's only storing the current 102 address book. e.g.  something likecurrent_102_address_book
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: ijungmann

timeline.bodyText: Can drop the cacheNames, cacheManager and key with my above recommendations.
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText: I've removed the cacheNames and cacheManager, letting it use the default key gen is causing issues with my unit test to retrieve it, I'm looking into how to fix that.
replies.author: ijungmann

timeline.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: ijungmann

timeline.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: ijungmann

timeline.message:
Revert Address Book Repository changes due to new caching logic

Signed-off-by: Ian Jungmann <ian.jungmann@hedera.com>

timeline.bodyText: the cached address book is built from file 102, here update() may be passed either file 101 or 102, so an update from file 101 will unnecessarily evict the cache
timeline.author: xin-hedera
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -63,6 +68,8 @@
      * @param fileData file data entry containing address book bytes
      */
     @Override
+    @CacheEvict(cacheNames = ADDRESS_BOOK_CACHE_NAME, cacheManager = NEVER_EXPIRE_LARGE, key =

replies.bodyText:
This has been changed to evict the entire cache.
I think 102 is still going to get altered in this case, the updatePreviousAddressBook() method looks for the previous 102 address book and updates it.
replies.author: ijungmann

replies.bodyText: gotcha!
replies.author: xin-hedera

replies.bodyText: You're correct, except that I think that logic is actually a bug. We shouldn't hardcode 102 in updatePreviousAddressBook()
replies.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText: Nana opened #1229
replies.author: steven-sheehy
